image.altText: A message on an eftpos machine saying there is an issue and to check connection.

items.synopsis: Train lines came to a halt, cafes couldn't take payment, triple-0 calls didn't go through. The Optus outage was more than just an inconvenience for millions of Australians.

title.children: How the Optus outage disrupted millions of Australians

image.altText: A smart phone with the message "Emergency calls only - YES OPTUS" where their signal bars should be.

items.synopsis: It's the day after the Optus outage struck more than 10 million customers and impacted health, education, transport and many other services. The company says the network is restored, but some people say they are still having problems.

title.children: Users they still don't have internet despite Optus outage being 'restored' last night

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A few of you have commented saying that your internet access was restored yesterday, but have lost your connections this morning. Here's a handful of updates from across the nation: In Brisbane and got our NBN back yesterday evening but we've lost it again this morning. Mobile services still working. — Chris Kewdale WA no internet service here. 07.00 Thurs. — Tony Optus NBN was restored yesterday around 12.30pm however went down again the morning at around 07.00 am and is yet to come back. Contacting Optus is proving to be impossible. — Timbo Service is out again in Deagon, QLD. I’d had been restored yesterday around 2pm and worked overnight. Dropped at 9am this morning and had been out since 1 — Jon Still no Optus NBN in Blackwood, Adelaide, SA. Modem restarted multiple times. I had to work from the local library yesterday, now hotspotting from my phone as I work from home. — Cathy Still no NBN service in Inner Southern suburb of Adelaide. Restarted the routers. Router is running off of backup sim card which can't handle the bandwidth. Tried to livechat with Optus support on the app but they've left me on 'read' for 10 minutes with zero reply so far. — Nic
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Scattered reports that Optus NBN is still down

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The blog hasn't fully fired up this morning, so the comments queue is currently clear. But after going through the messages we received from our reader submission portal, I can see some of you are still having problems this morning. Here's a sample of some of the updates we've had from readers already today: We are Optus customers for our nbn broadband. We live in Toowoomba Qld. Our internet and landline services have not been restored as of 0549hts Thurs 9th Nov. We have not heard from Optus at all over the past 24hrs. Unable to complete online studies yesterday. We also had personal data hacked in the cyber attack. Optus have not compensated us in any way. — Kim I have not got paid — Michelle I live in Coffs Harbour and my internet services were not resumed until this morning. So Optus saying the issue was fixed by 6pm yesterday is wrong. — Barbara I am still off-line, unable to access any internet that on a daily basis I am continually sent Optus messages they are fixing NBN faults, it is abysmal service — Sue These comments have come in from people responding to our callout. The link for that page is below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Some readers say they are still having problems

featuredLink.title: Have you been affected by the Optus outage? Tell us your story

— Sue
These comments have come in from people responding to our callout.
The link for that page is below.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning, Hopefully your day started off better than yesterday! Today we're going to be focusing on the fallout of the Optus outage that brought some services and businesses to a halt — or, at the very least, made things difficult. The latest update from Optus was last night at precisely 6.32pm AEDT. Here's what the company's website says: The Optus Network has been restored and most services should now be back on line. Some customers may need to restart their device or turn flight mode on then off. Some NBN connections may not be restored as yet. Please try restarting your modem by turning it off, unplugging it for 30 seconds, and restarting. Our people are doing their best to respond to your concerns and Optus sincerely apologises for today’s outage. We again thank customers for their patience. We'll be bringing you all the updates as they come in this morning.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What's the latest Optus outage update?

children.content: Good morning,
Hopefully your day started off better than yesterday!
Today we're going to be focusing on the fallout of the Optus outage that brought some services and businesses to a halt — or, at the very least, made things difficult.
The latest update from Optus was last night at precisely 6.32pm AEDT.
Here's what the company's website says:
The Optus Network has been restored
and
most services should now be back on line
Some customers may need to restart their device or turn flight mode on then off.
Some NBN connections may not be restored as yet
. Please try restarting your modem by turning it off, unplugging it for 30 seconds, and restarting.
Our people are doing their best to respond to your concerns and Optus sincerely apologises for today’s outage.
We again thank customers for their patience.
We'll be bringing you all the updates as they come in this morning.

items.synopsis: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken says Palestinians must be able to self-govern in Gaza, as well as the West Bank, under a unified Palestinian Authority after the war, saying it's "clear that Israel cannot reoccupy Gaza". Follow live.

title.children: 'Israel cannot reoccupy Gaza': US's top diplomat outlines vision for Palestinian rule in Gaza

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Rafah border crossing into Gaza was closed on Wednesday due to an unspecified "security circumstance" but US officials were working with Egypt and Israel to get it reopened. "Our understanding is that given a security circumstance, the Rafah border crossing remains closed today," State Department deputy spokesperson Vedant Patel said during a regular press briefing. "This is an incredibly fluid situation. The border crossing has opened on many instances and allowed for the safe … exit for foreign nationals who have sought it," he said. Evacuations of foreign passport holders through the crossing were suspended on Saturday and Sunday after an Israeli strike on an ambulance that was heading to Rafah, but the crossing was open again on Monday and Tuesday. The US expects the Egypt-controlled crossing will be reopened at "regular intervals" so that aid can enter the Gaza Strip and foreign nationals can continue to depart, Mr Patel said. He said 81 trucks carrying food, medicine, health supplies, bottled water and hygiene products crossed into the strip on Tuesday, bringing to about 650 the total number of trucks that have crossed since a diplomatic agreement was reached to reopen the crossing on October 21. Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rafah crossing closed for 'security circumstance' after 81 aid trucks went through, US says

children.content: The Rafah border crossing into Gaza was closed on Wednesday due to an unspecified "security circumstance" but US officials were working with Egypt and Israel to get it reopened.
"Our understanding is that given a security circumstance, the Rafah border crossing remains closed today," State Department deputy spokesperson Vedant Patel said during a regular press briefing.
"This is an incredibly fluid situation. The border crossing has opened on many instances and allowed for the safe … exit for foreign nationals who have sought it," he said.

Evacuations of foreign passport holders through the crossing were suspended on Saturday and Sunday after an Israeli strike on an ambulance that was heading to Rafah, but the crossing was open again on Monday and Tuesday.

props.alt: A satelltie view of a border with car parked on one side and dirt surrouning

children.content: A satellite image shows a closer view of the Rafah border crossing between Gaza and Egypt on November 7
(Maxar Technologie via Reuters)
The US expects the Egypt-controlled crossing will be reopened at "regular intervals" so that aid can enter the Gaza Strip and foreign nationals can continue to depart, Mr Patel said.

He said 81 trucks carrying food, medicine, health supplies, bottled water and hygiene products crossed into the strip on Tuesday, bringing to about 650 the total number of trucks that have crossed since a diplomatic agreement was reached to reopen the crossing on October 21.
Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In the occupied West Bank, Israeli forces wounded 19 Palestinians in shooting on Wednesday during a raid on the city of Bethlehem that lasted more than six hours, leaving four people in critical condition, the Palestinian health ministry said. The Palestinian Prisoners Association said Israeli forces arrested some 65 people across the West Bank on Wednesday, raising the number of Palestinians detained since October 7 to 2,280. There was no immediate comment from the Israeli military. It came as Israeli PM Benjamin Netanyahu met with leaders of Israeli settlements in the West Bank and denounced acts of sometimes-deadly vigilante violence committed by hard-line Israelis against Palestinian civilians. "We are not prepared to tolerate it, we are not about to accept it, we will act against it in every way," Netanyahu said. He praised the settlers, who live in communities established by Israel on territory captured from Jordan in a 1967 war which are widely viewed as illegal under international law and on land Palestinians hope may one day be part of a future Palestinian state. Vigilante-style settler attacks have killed at least 29 people this year, according to the UN Humanitarian Affairs Office, OCHA. Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: West Bank raid injures 19 as Netanyahu denounces settler violence

children.content: In the occupied West Bank, Israeli forces wounded 19 Palestinians in shooting on Wednesday during a raid on the city of Bethlehem that lasted more than six hours, leaving four people in critical condition, the Palestinian health ministry said.
The Palestinian Prisoners Association said Israeli forces arrested some 65 people across the West Bank on Wednesday, raising the number of Palestinians detained since October 7 to 2,280.
There was no immediate comment from the Israeli military.

It came as Israeli PM Benjamin Netanyahu met with leaders of Israeli settlements in the West Bank and denounced acts of sometimes-deadly vigilante violence committed by hard-line Israelis against Palestinian civilians.
"We are not prepared to tolerate it, we are not about to accept it, we will act against it in every way," Netanyahu said.

He praised the settlers, who live in communities established by Israel on territory captured from Jordan in a 1967 war which are widely viewed as illegal under international law and on land Palestinians hope may one day be part of a future Palestinian state.
Vigilante-style settler attacks have killed at least 29 people this year, according to the UN Humanitarian Affairs Office, OCHA.
Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The US's top diplomat says Palestinians must be able to self-govern in Gaza, as well as the West Bank, under a unified Palestinian Authority after the war. It comes after Israeli PM Benjamin Netanyahu suggested his country would maintain security control of Gaza for an "indefinite period" after its bombardment, which has killed 10,500 people in a month, according to Palestinian health authorities. US Secretary of State Antony Blinken has laid out the most detail to date about America's vision for a post-war two-state solution. He said the "key elements" should include: No forcible displacement of Palestinians from Gaza. "Not now, not after the war." No use of Gaza as a platform for terrorism No reoccupation of Gaza after the war No attempt to blockade or besiege Gaza It's "clear that Israel cannot reoccupy Gaza", Blinken said. "We must also work on the affirmative elements to get to a sustained peace. These must include the Palestinian people's voices and aspirations at the centre of post-crisis governance in Gaza. It must include Palestinian-led governance, and Gaza unified with the West Bank under the Palestinian Authority." Mr Blinken's comments highlight a widening gap between the US and Israel on the longer-term goals for the region. None of the ideas that Israeli officials have raised for Gaza's governance after the war have included independent Palestinian rule as a credible possibility. Reporting with AP
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Israel cannot reoccupy Gaza,' says Blinken, outlining vision for Palestinian rule

props.alt: Antony Blinken stands at a podium in front of a USA flag, with Japanese flags beside him.

children.content: Antony Blinken made the comments after a G7 meeting in Tokyo
(AP: Jonathan Ernst/Pool)
The US's top diplomat says Palestinians must be able to self-govern in Gaza, as well as the West Bank, under a unified Palestinian Authority after the war.

It comes after Israeli PM Benjamin Netanyahu suggested his country would maintain security control of Gaza for an "indefinite period" after its bombardment, which has killed 10,500 people in a month, according to Palestinian health authorities.
US Secretary of State Antony Blinken has laid out the most detail to date about America's vision for a post-war two-state solution.
He said the "key elements" should include:
No forcible displacement of Palestinians from Gaza. "Not now, not after the war."
No use of Gaza as a platform for terrorism
No reoccupation of Gaza after the war
No attempt to blockade or besiege Gaza
It's "clear that Israel cannot reoccupy Gaza", Blinken said.

"We must also work on the affirmative elements to get to a sustained peace. These must include the Palestinian people's voices and aspirations at the centre of post-crisis governance in Gaza. It must include Palestinian-led governance, and Gaza unified with the West Bank under the Palestinian Authority."
Mr Blinken's comments highlight a widening gap between the US and Israel on the longer-term goals for the region.
None of the ideas that Israeli officials have raised for Gaza's governance after the war have included independent Palestinian rule as a credible possibility.
Reporting with AP

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market has started the day higher, with industrials (+1.2%) and education (1.1%) stocks leading the gains. Eight of the 11 sectors were trading higher at open. However, the tech (-0.4%) and energy (-0.7%) sectors were down. The ASX 200 index was up 21 points to 7,015 points, by 10:15am AEDT. Biggest gains: Sayona Mining +5.8% to $0.09 Orica +3.3% to $15.56 Block +2.9% to $81.19 Polynovo +2.9% to $1.41 South32 +2.1% to $3.18 Biggest losses: Xero -5.4% to $108.70 Newmont Corp -4.7% to $53.30 Healius -2.8% to $1.92 Resmed -2.8% to $23.17 Westpac -2.5% to $21.10
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX opens up

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: More than 800 large companies paid no tax in 2021-22, an Australian Taxation Office (ATO) report reveals. The ATO's ninth corporate tax transparency report, which covers 2,713 corporate entities, found that while the amount of tax collected increased due to skyrocketing mining company profits and higher oil prices, there were still 831 (31 per cent) that did not pay a cent of tax. The report attributes no tax being paid to various reasons, including companies making an accounting loss or claiming tax offsets that reduced their tax bill to nil. Read more from business reporter Nassim Khadem .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ATO reveals the more than 800 companies that paid no tax

featuredLink.title: ATO reveals the more than 800 companies that paid no tax

ninth corporate tax transparency report, which covers 2,713 corporate entities, found that while the amount of tax collected increased due to skyrocketing mining company profits and higher oil prices, there were still 831 (31 per cent) that did not pay a cent of
tax.
The report attributes no tax being paid to various reasons, including companies making an accounting loss or claiming tax offsets that reduced their tax bill to nil.

Nassim Khadem
